ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PORK STALL HOLDERS
(Use of chillers)


    1. Mr Harun A. Ghani asked the Minister for the Environment (a) if he will give some indication of the response by stall holders to the Government's policy requiring them to sell meat in chillers; and (b) whether there has been reservation by customers in accepting chilled meat sold in markets.

    The Minister for the Environment (Mr Lee Yock Suan): Mr Speaker, Sir, pork stall holders appear to be generally happy with

Column: 1722

the use of chillers to retail fresh pork. Some have indicated that their volume of sale has increased. They are now able to sell fresh chilled pork obtained from approved farms overseas whereas in the past they could only sell fresh pork slaughtered in the abattoirs in Singapore.

    The public have also taken the chilled meat system well. They have found the chiller system to be cleaner and more hygienic.

Column: 1722

VACANT HAWKER STALLS


    2. Mr Harun A Ghani asked the Minister for the Environment if he will give some indication (a) how many stall holders have given up their stalls; (b) how many have changed their trade; and (c) whether his Ministry will consider allocating vacant stalls for hardship cases, especially those stalls which have not been taken up by tenders.

    Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Speaker Sir, each year an average of 320 stall holders, or 1.7%, give up their stalls and another 50, or 0.3%, change their trade.

    The vacant stalls are tendered out and an average of 300 stalls are filled each year in this manner.

    The decision to tender out vacant hawker stalls to the general public instead of allocating them to hardship cases was taken in 1990 for several reasons. Operating a hawker stall is a business that requires a financial investment and good culinary skills. Many "hardship" cases allotted stalls in the past were unable to operate their stalls profitably and their businesses failed, leading to more financial hardship. Some resorted to subletting their stalls illegally.

    The hawker business is best left to people with adequate resources and culinary skills whilst "hardship" cases should seek other forms of employment or assistance.

    Mr Harun A. Ghani (Hong Kah): Could the Minister tell us how many of the "hardship" cases were not up to standard and they had to give up their stalls?

Column: 1723



    Mr Lee Yock Suan: I do not quite get the question. The policy to allocate stalls to hardship cases was started in 1975 and the policy was stopped in 1990. When the policy was reviewed, it was felt that there was no longer a need for the policy. Maybe I can give an idea of the situation at that time. There were then a total of 648 approved hardship cases on the waiting list. In 1990, when the policy was stopped, a total of 212 vacant cooked food stalls and 1,621 market produce stalls were offered to them. However, there were no takers. In fact, all 648 cases had not selected a stall for nine months and 538 had not selected any stalls for over a year. In fact, most of them were not really in dire need of a stall. Many of them could not operate the stalls. They were hoping to get stalls in good locations so that they could sublet to other people and, indirectly, get a subsidy for living allowance.

    Assoc. Prof. Chin Tet Yung (Sembawang): Sir, I would like to raise three matters concerning road safety. First, can the Ministry look into whether the entry and exit points on certain highways, such as the CTE, be resited, particularly one that involves a confluence of points on to the CTE. For example, first, the confluence of two exits, one from the PIE and the other from Toa Payoh, as we

Column: 1724

approach the CTE. Next, these two then converge on to the CTE just at the point when the CTE has an exit point into Farrer Road. This, I believe, is why every evening we see the sign, "Heavy traffic up to Braddell". In the same way from the other side of the CTE going towards the city, every morning we have virtually the same problem so that we see the warning, "Heavy traffic from Ang Mo Kio Avenue 3 or 1 to the PIE". Arguably, these must be the most congested areas and it may well be due to the misplacement of exit and entry points. So I hope that the Ministry can do something about alleviating the conditions by resiting exit and entry points on this particular stretch.

    Second, could LTA look into more road safety indicators to prevent two bad habits? The first is the tendency of drivers and motorcyclists to cut into lanes or weave in and out of lanes, especially on the expressways. I wonder whether installation of devices, such as cat's eyes, would be one way of discouraging this irritating and often dangerous behaviour.

    The second bad habit is tailgating, particularly, on bus lanes. Could the Ministry, for example, consider the use of chevrons on the roads, particularly on the fast lanes to indicate safe distances that cars should have between them. Too often, we have had multiple car pile-ups because of tailgating.

    Third, could LTA consider the banning of fog lights? I know that, recently, LTA has responded in the Forum pages to say that such lights would be permitted. But very often, on clear nights, there appears to be a lunatic freak who drives a certain mark of car, I think it is German, who delights in switching on these lights that usually blind all others even if we were to view them from the rear view mirror. Such inconsiderate people never seem to learn the lesson. And such lights are supposed to be switched on when there are hazardous conditions. But in Singapore, these lights themselves actually form the real hazard. So I hope the Ministry will look into these matters.

Column: 1725



    Mdm Claire Chiang See Ngoh (Nominated Member): Sir, I have raised this issue in this House before and I would like to hear a commitment from the Minister that, at the policy level, his Ministry will review transportation safety for school children from the ages of 3 to 12 who are travelling to and from school in buses. The review will consist of working out the costs of fitting school buses with bus seats befitting the size and leg length of children of varying ages, beginning with those of a child as little as 3 years old. The review will address the costs also of fitting the back seats of the car with padding so as to cushion any concussion that may result from a sudden brake by the driver. The Ministry will establish and continually assess the driving competence of bus drivers. They would ensure that each bus has a competent assistant who is able to discipline the children by making sure that they are seated and belted and who is capable of crisis-management should an accident happen.

    Sir, the Minister of State told me, during the last sitting, that there were no fatal accidents linked to transportation of school children in kindergartens. Therefore, there was no need for seat belts or to refit current fleet of school buses. I also learnt that the same vans or buses which are ferrying school children at other times are used by older students and adults as well, therefore making it less cost effective for the bus operator to fit his buses only for use by a limited category of young children.

    Sir, for me, safety is an issue which cannot be compromised or calculated on principles of cost effectiveness. Unless we study the problem and the latest development on car fittings, we cannot be so sure that the cost is unaffordable. In any case, the principle of best practice on transportation safety must be safeguarded irrespective of costs and pragmatic reasoning. A speed limit cannot serve as a safety substitute. We all know that a sudden brake, even when driving at the slowest speed, can succeed in throwing the child towards the window screen and cracking his or her neck.

Column: 1726



    I urge the Minister not to delay in studying this issue seriously. It is better to err on the side of caution. We may not have had fatal accidents, but certainly, we must protect our children from being maimed due to our failure in not spending a few hundred dollars more in fitting out the buses. One real concern is the unhappiness of parents if they were to pay more for transportation because the costs of refitting the buses will mean passing the costs on to the users. Surely, if any government is capable of making its people accept a good policy despite its price hikes, it is our Government. And surely, the fear of unhappy public reaction cannot be a good reason for not doing something that is right in the first place.

    Should the role of the Government be one of a protector in the interests of the school children, or that of a defender on behalf of the commercial interests of bus operators? The Government must balance this conflicting role in favour of the children. For me, as a mother, the decision is clearly evident. I will pay for my child's safety because he or she is priceless. For those parents who cannot afford it, the school and other supportive parents can help to subsidise transportation charges for their children. I repeat, Sir, our children's safety cannot be compromised.

    Dr Teo Ho Pin (Sembawang): Sir, Singapore has 3,120 kilometres of roads and 700,000 vehicles on the roads. As we progress to become a vibrant metropolis, we will expect our roads to be more busy, especially during the night. We are also a fast ageing population and there will be a higher proportion of drivers between the age of 50 and 60 years old in the years to come.

    To date, we have many different types of road markings and signages on our roads. The road signages come in different sizes, fonts, colours and shapes. These road signages are usually placed at ad hoc locations and can be untidy and sometimes confusing. The recent change of the tourist attractions' road signages to brown is indeed a correct step towards standardising our road signages and making them more user friendly.

Column: 1727



    Sir, there are also many road markings on our roads. Some of these road markings are necessary and also confusing. The extensive road markings on our roads also increase the maintenance cost, and affect the smooth flow of traffic as they need frequent maintenance and repainting.

    Sir, I would like to seek the Minister's clarifications on the following:

    (1) What is the policy for deciding where to place road signages and road markings?

    (2) How much is spent on road signages and markings maintenance per year?

    (3) What are the measures taken by the Ministry to ensure that all road signages and markings are visible, especially at night?

    Assoc. Prof. Chin Tet Yung: Sir, last year, the Ministry adopted the bold move of not fining the ERP violators from the start, but by asking them to pay an administrative charge and the relevant ERP fee. This has been seen as a good move by the Ministry which should be congratulated for this.

    I wonder whether this example should not serve as a model for treating other types of offences that are, so to speak, victimless. I will give an example. Last year, a mother and her six-year old child was caught eating while they were leaving an MRT station. They had already gone through the electronic barrier and the mother thought that they were out of the restricted zone as it were. However, they were unpleasantly surprised when they were accosted while their mouths were bulging with paus and given summonses. The officer did not listen to their explanation, which was that the mother made a genuine mistake and it took two letters of appeal before LTA decided to let them off. But once again, may I say that I am grateful to LTA for letting them off.

Column: 1728



    However, this has led me to wonder whether we are doing the right thing by banning, for example, eating and drinking, when what we are interested in is to punish littering. It is not what we put inside our stomachs. Surely that is the issue. I am all for imposing fines for littering because that is definitely a matter of public hygiene. But banning eating and drinking, perhaps, needs reconsideration. Perhaps, a public education programme would be better.

    Going through the Mass Rapid Transit Corporation's regulations, I can give other examples where the first response had been to summon the person and to give penalties. I refer especially, for example, to non-compliance with instructions of an LTA officer, $500 fine; entering into and remaining in train when it is full, $500 fine; feet placed on seats, $500 fine; spitting and littering, $500 fine; playing musical instruments, $500 fine; throwing missiles, $5,000 fine. I know all these fines are compounded but these are matters that I thought could be dealt with first by having a public education programme, rather than by imposing penalties straightaway on such undesirable modes of conduct.

    Sir, I hope that LTA will consider reviewing their whole structure of regulatory offences to see whether the first response should be through the criminal sanction. Using criminal sanction as first response for certain types of conduct can be akin to using a machine gun against a guy armed with a bow and arrow. What I am saying is that a good public education programme should be tried out first and, if it does really become a problem, for example, if the trains become littered with rubbish, then I would say that the criminal sanction would be justified. I hope that LTA would pursue more the line of public education rather than punitive measures.

    Assoc. Prof. Toh See Kiat (Aljunied): Sir, any visitor who travels on our roads will invariably get the impression that we have very new cars and generally green cars which do not pollute the air. That same

Column: 1729

visitor would be forgiven if he, at the same time, thinks that as far as our buses, vans, taxis and motorcycles go, however, the norm is that of a trail of black smoke. Perhaps, the authorities here give some special exemption from anti-pollution laws to commercial vehicles and motorcycles. That impression should be corrected.

    Vehicles which spew pollutants reduce the quality of air that we rely on to live. It is an issue which we must address as a matter of survival. Vehicles using fossil fuels also drain our financial resources, as these fuels have to be imported at great cost from a cartel of nations which do not necessarily have our nation's interests at heart. Therefore, we must look at alternatives to the diesel or petrol driven vehicles for the sake of our health, finances and national security.

    To cut our reliance on fossil fuels totally may not be feasible, but we can reduce that reliance. After all, we will be getting plenteous amounts of natural gas from Indonesia soon. Being a tropical country, we are also blessed with lots of free sunshine. There are many alternatives which use these sources of energy: electric cars which have become quite reliable with advances in, for example, battery technology; hybrid cars which allow electric cars to travel beyond the city; liquid petroleum gas (LPG) cars which use natural gas, and even solar-powered cars.

    It is thus surprising to me that the Government is not putting in more effort to permit the use of such vehicles in Singapore. Could we not give tax incentives, for example, to those who import such vehicles and the fuel that is needed for such vehicles, or rebates for those who use these cars and tax reliefs for those who have to build the infrastructure, such as the fuel stations, to service and maintain such vehicles?

    I look forward to the day when, because of such measures, we will have cleaner air, cheaper fuels and cheaper cars and, best of all, we can cock a snook at the petrol cartels.

Column: 1730



    Dr Lily Neo (Kreta Ayer-Tanglin): Sir, I would like to seek the indulgence of the Minister for Communications and Information Technology to consider the future of post-war classic cars in Singapore. We are referring to those post-war cars that are more than 20 years old and quite apart from those pre-war vintage cars that already enjoy special privileges.

    There is a need to look into this matter now because most of these cars have 10-year certificates of entitlement (COEs) that will expire in May 2000. These cars are restored and well-maintained by enthusiasts and they are to be considered a heritage of ours worth preserving. The problem, Sir, is that the costs and returns to continue preserving them are too foreboding under these current circumstances:

    1) the prevailing quota premium (PQP) is about $50,000 and this is far too exorbitant in relation to the car values;

    2) a payment of the full PQP will not be commensurate with the usual amount of usage of these cars; and

    3) the payment of PQP has to be on a 10-yearly basis in order to qualify for future COE extensions.

    Sir, many of the owners are not able to afford the impending outlay for the COEs and they will have to either export or scrap their cars. This will be most unfortunate and it would, therefore, be good if the Minister alleviates the situation by endorsing a "classic car category" fairly soon. The more than 20-year post-war cars could then be accorded some privileges similar to those for the "vintage car category".

    The Land Transport Authority would have to collaborate with the relevant involved parties to formulate the criteria and rules. It is necessary to be prudent and avoid two situations. Firstly, a "bonanza" situation should not be created in these cars and especially in the "new" 20 year olds when privileges are accorded. Secondly, an increase in the number of "bad" cars on our roads. This may happen

Column: 1731

when poorly maintained "new" 20 year-old cars get registered in the "classic car category" instead of being scrapped. Perhaps having the cars qualify for categorisation initially and imposing punitive transfer fees may ensure only valued and well-maintained cars remain in the scheme.

    Sir, we are encouraged to preserve and to appreciate our history and heritage. In line with this, I would like to persuade the Minister to enable us to continue keeping our classic cars.

    Mr Gerard Ee (Nominated Member): Sir, Singapore is probably the most expensive place in the world to buy and own a car. It all started many years ago when the car population exploded and there was a need to dampen the demand for cars to deal with congestions, which carries a high economic cost. We introduced the ARF, and then PARF, CBD, COE, RPS and ERP. There was a time when COE for bigger cars fetched a price of $100,000. In spite of the high cost of owning a car, demand for COEs remains in excess of the supply. This is partly due to the aspiration to own a car and to a great extent, due to convenience, bordering on necessity.

    Much has been done and is being done to extend the network of public transport. Undoubtedly, we already have a public transportation system that we can be proud of. However, we only have to look at the queues of vehicles outside the schools to see but one important and indispensable use of the car. Many mothers have made the sacrifice to care for their young children and part of their daily routine includes the ferrying of their children to and from school for classes, ECA activities, and to tuitions. For the mothers, having a car is not a convenience, but a necessity. The alternative would be that their children would have to wake up before 5 am and prepare for the school bus, and what about the activities outside school hours.

    We now have an effective means of dealing with congestion. We have in place

Column: 1732

the Electronic Road Pricing system that is unique in the world. Its effectiveness has attracted attention and I believe that there are interests shown by other countries to implement a similar system. As a result, the ARF has been reduced and the scale for road tax has been smoothened.

    A broken down vehicle inevitably causes congestion. There is belief that older vehicles would have a higher tendency to break down. Well, new cars do break down too. In any case, cars being retained beyond their 10th anniversary are subjected to a revalidation of the COE, premium on the road tax, which amounts to 50% from the 15th year on, and an annual vehicle inspection. That is a lot to pay for any person. Whilst it is easier to explain about the revalidation of the COE, given that it has a validity period of only 10 years, it is almost impossible to sound convincing about the premium on road taxes since cars older than 10 years are subjected to an annual inspection. Of course, the inspection is to check on certain main safety aspects of the vehicle and cannot give much comfort on the overall reliability of the vehicle. Vehicles can break down minutes after passing a vehicle inspection.

    Thus, as motorists, we bear with the costs. However, except for the ERP, which is usage based, other policies are non-discriminating. A person who uses the car occasionally for essential purposes only is equally penalised on cost as the person who uses the car indiscriminately, such as driving to the provision store just five minutes away. With the COE, the growth in the vehicle population is controlled. It cannot grow faster than the number of COEs being released.

    With the ERP, vehicles are kept away from the main arterial roads to keep them relatively congestion-free.

    It is time that those who keep their cars in good condition are rewarded. A badly maintained car will break down even if it is just a year old. Whilst whether a car is in good condition can only be determined by a thorough inspection, an effective alternative measure would be that if it is still

Column: 1733

running well, in spite of being over 20 years old, it must have been reasonably well-looked after.

    I urge the Minister to:

    1) introduce a more thorough annual inspection scheme for vehicles older than 10 years and remove the road tax premium on such cars; and

    2) introduce a special scheme for cars older than 20 years for restricted usage. The main aim of such a scheme would be to reduce the ownership cost of keeping a car beyond 20 years. Without proper maintenance, it is very unlikely that a vehicle would be retained beyond 20 years. There are many well-manufactured cars that, with proper care, can be used on the roads for many decades. This will avoid wastage where serviceable cars are scrapped and worse, if it is replaced, our foreign exchange reserve will be drawn on to pay the foreign manufacturer.

    A special scheme for older cars would benefit the retirees. We are making the call for active ageing. If we want older persons to remain in the workforce or volunteer their services, we should, at the very least, make it affordable for them to retain their personal mode of transportation.

    The average person would make a major upgrade when he or she is around 45 years old. 20 years on, the person would be 65 years old and approaching retirement or retired. The person will have less use of the vehicle but would like to keep it. After working hard and contributing to the Singapore's economy all these years, it would not be asking much to make it affordable for him to retain his vehicle if he so wishes. He will be subjected to the ERP, like anyone, and would likewise have to use the vehicle discriminatingly. As a bonus, Singapore will have its own pool of heritage cars that would, in time, be viewed as vintage cars. We will have on our roads a living history of the evolution of cars used in Singapore.

    For your consideration, Minister.

    Mr Yeo Guat Kwang (Cheng San)(In Mandarin): Sir, most people in

Column: 1734

Singapore basically understand that as a small nation with limited land to use, we need to have a set of highly efficient land transport system and a vehicle control system, to make sure that our roads are free flowing. The roads and rail networks are like the blood vessels in our body. If the blood vessels are blocked, then the body will be partially or completely paralysed. Singapore is the only country in the world that has successfully implemented the COE and ERP systems. However, we cannot just depend on all these control measures, because clothing, food, accommodation and transportation are the four essential conditions in our life. When everybody wants to own a car and there are not enough roads for the cars to move, we have to do something. We have to build a very good network, a rail network or an integrated public transport system. These are very important to us.

    The rail network has progressed very rapidly in the last few years. The MRT system enables us to travel from east to west and from north to south. The Airport line and the North-East Line will be completed in 2001 and 2002 respectively. An effective MRT system has also let us to make optimum use of our land. I would like to know whether the Government has any plans to extend the rail network to all the major residential estates, so that they could be linked up.

    In 1995, the former Communications Minister, Mr Mah Bow Tan, and the GPC Chairman, Dr Tan Cheng Bock, visited many countries in the world, and recommended the LRT system in 1995. The LRT will become an important mode of transport in our HDB estates.

    Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong announced the first LRT system in February 1996, and thereafter the Government has also announced LRT systems in Bukit Panjang, Sengkang and Punggol, and the people were very excited about this. After this, the residents in the other estates have been waiting and waiting, and yet they do not hear any news of LRT coming to their new towns. I would like to ask the Minister whether

Column: 1735

we are going to extend our LRT system to the other residential estates.

    Sir, apart from the rail network, our road network should also be improved. Last year, in the Budget debate, I mentioned that ERP is a specific and effective cure, but not a panacea. We must expand our road network and to clear some of the bottleneck situations in some of our roads. It is like a patient who has an artery blockage problem. If necessary, we may have to get a specialist to put in a stent, so that the blood vessels will be free again. Otherwise, we may even have to perform an operation on them.

    Sir, to ensure that the immigration offender problem remains in check, the Home Team has taken a multi-pronged approach to deal with this problem comprehensively. For example, we have enhanced our border control. We have continued with intensive enforcement efforts against the traffickers, the employers as well as the harbourers. Police and Immigration have also conducted raids in areas where immigration offenders are likely to gather to work or live. Let me elaborate on this.

    In the past year, the Police and the Singapore Immigration and Registration raided various immigration offender haunts, including construction sites, workplaces, forested areas and known congregation areas. The Police conducted 15 major island-wide operations throughout 1999, resulting in the arrest of 1,400 illegal immigrants and 185 overstayers. In addition, 17 operations were conducted

Column: 1814

in the forested areas, with 195 illegal immigrants and 27 overstayers arrested.

    The Police also targeted the employers of immigration offenders and the harbourers at their residential premises, such as our HDB flats and also in private estates. Since we stepped up enforcement in early 1998, it is now more difficult to find congregations of immigration offenders at any particular location. The Police has therefore widened its net to include entertainment outlets in the crackdown on immigration offenders. For example, in October last year, 100 immigration offenders were arrested in a discotheque in Orchard Road.

The Police Coast Guard also deploys monitoring posts equipped with surveillance equipment and systems at strategic locations to detect these illegal landings. The Police Coast Guard's enhanced presence has thwarted many illegal immigration attempts. In 1999, the Police Coast Guard foiled 52 attempts and arrested close to 240 illegal immigrants. To stay on top in its fight against immigration offenders and the smugglers, the Police Coast Guard recently added 20 high speed patrol boats equipped with the latest surveillance and digital communication equipment and six highly manouverable speedboats or interceptor speedboats to its fleet. Illegal immigrants and traffickers who try to sneak in by sea will therefore be up against these high performance boats. The Police Coast Guard will continue to upgrade its fleet to ensure that it is sufficiently equipped to handle the threats and the challenges it faces.

checkpoints, without adversely affecting traffic flow, because if it starts to check everybody, then I am sure people will complain that there are long queues of vehicles and long lines of people queuing at our immigration counters.

For example, 60 illegal immigrant traffickers were arrested and 52 vehicles seized in 1999, compared to only 42 illegal immigrant traffickers arrested and 23 vehicles seized in the year 1998. Many of these illegal immigrants who were arrested were trying to enter Singapore or leave Singapore by concealing themselves in the car boots or in special compartments of travel coaches, lorries or bus kilangs. This case clearly shows the ruthless nature of the traffickers of these immigration offenders. They will go to no end just to earn a quick dollar without caring for the safety of the people in the vehicle.

    Police and immigration are also now focusing on crippling the syndicates that are responsible for trafficking these immigration offenders and giving these offenders forged documents. With the stringent checks in place, the syndicates have been finding new ways to send these illegal immigrants through the land checkpoints. From using lorries and buses or hiding in car boots, the syndicates are now resorting to using special compartments in the vehicles or ferrying these illegal immigrants by car or lorry to somewhere near the checkpoint and then ask these illegal immigrants to find their own way into Singapore, or out of Singapore.

Such action by the syndicates is a sign of their desperation, in view of the stringent checks and enforcement by the authorities. The evolving nature of the problem means that the Home Team has to be alert and stay on top of the problem and be responsive to the new methods of operation of these syndicates. We will seek deterrent sentences against these syndicate members who are arrested.

    But the responsibility for tackling the immigration offender problem does not just lie with the Home Team alone. The public, too, has a role to play. Singaporeans should not create the demand for immigration offenders by employing them. That is very important. And neither should Singaporeans harbour them by renting out their premises, flats, private apartments or houses to them. In 1999, 388 employers were arrested, compared to 270 arrested in 1998 for hiring these immigration offenders. 306 harbourers were also arrested last year compared to 166 in 1998. All these were because of stepped-up enforcement by Police and immigration.

    Home-owners with premises to let out should be more careful when selecting their prospective tenants, because many of these home-owners claimed that they did not check this or that, or they simply checked the copy without looking at the original copy. What they should do is to check the prospective tenants' original copy of the immigration and work passes and then cross-check to make sure that the particulars on the passports tally with those of the work passes. In addition, where the names of the employers appear on the work passes, then the home-owners should also check with the employers to verify that the prospective tenants are indeed employed by these employers. If not, they will find themselves in great difficulty explaining to the court. If the home-owners are in doubt of the genuineness of the pass or about the status of the person, or even about his work status, then, they should contact the immigration authorities during office hours or check with the information and services counters of the Work Permit Department of the Manpower Ministry to

verify the genuineness or the authenticity of these passes.

So there is no reason why foreign worker would not be able to produce the original copy of their work permits on demand. Landlords should be suspicious if their prospective tenants say that their employer kept the original and that they have only a photocopy, or that their passports are with the employer and they have only a photocopy. When they receive such papers, they should question and insist on seeing the original copies. they have work permits. But the owner of the property has misused his property. He did not have the permission of the proper authority and I believe URA or BCA has taken action, and so has the Civil Defence Force.

To deter the harbouring of immigration offenders, the current Immigration Act imposes due diligence on the person letting out the accommodation to check and make sure that the prospective tenants are not immigration offenders. But my Ministry will now consider extending this legal requirement for due diligence by the landlords to those who act as facilitators or middlemen in a transaction to rent out the premises as well.
